title-group.article-title: Firm performance and aspiration levels as determinants of a firm’s strategic repositioning within strategic group structures

abstract.p: Previous studies on strategic group dynamics have generated valuable insights into the industry-level determinants of changes in strategic group membership and group strategy. Complementary to this line of research, the present study focuses on the firm-level determinants underlying shifts in firm positioning within strategic group structures. Drawing on the behavioral theory of the firm, the study examines the influence of firm performance and performance aspirations on the extent to which firms strategically diverge from or converge towards their strategic groups. Empirical results from a longitudinal analysis of the strategic repositioning by 1191 US insurance firms over a 10-year time period (1999–2008) suggest that firms performing below aspirations show a greater inclination to diverge from their current strategic group than firms performing above aspirations. Industry conditions are found to moderate the relationship between performance aspirations and strategic divergence–convergence. The study’s findings highlight the influence of performance feedback on strategic group dynamics, and the importance of considering the interplay between firm-level and industry-level characteristics in explaining strategic group dynamics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since Hunt (1972) initially grouped strategically similar firms within the appliance industry and dubbed these clusters ‘strategic groups’, numerous strategy scholars have adopted the strategic group concept. While early studies mostly focused on the identification of strategic groups in different industry settings and on the analysis of performance differences between strategic groups (e.g., Cool and Schendel, 1987; Newman, 1978), more recently research attention has shifted towards strategic group dynamics. Studies on strategic group dynamics are concerned with the evolution of strategic group structures (Lee et al., 2002; Mascarenhas, 1989; MásRuíz, 1999), including changes in strategic group membership (e.g., McNamara et al., 2003), and changes in average strategic group strategy (e.g., DeSarbo et al., 2009). An understanding of the evolution of strategic group structures is important for several reasons. It provides insights into an industry’s competitive dynamics, and may help explain performance differences between firms within the same industry, as well as changes in an industry’s overall profitability. Increasing research attention has thus been directed towards understanding the determinants of strategic repositioning within an industry’s strategic group structure (Bogner et al., 1996; Fiegenbaum et al., 2001; McNamara et al., 2003). This study contributes to this particular line of research on strategic group dynamics by examining how firm-, group-, and industry-level characteristics determine firms’ strategic repositioning within strategic group structures, leading to changes in group membership and group strategies. Specifically, the study focuses attention on the firm-level determinants underlying within- and across-group strategic repositioning rather than on the industry-level determinants which have been central to prior work on strategic group dynamics (e.g., Hergert, 1988; Mascarenhas, 1989; Zuniga-Vicente et al., 2004). Drawing on the behavioral theory of the firm (Cyert and March, 1963) and behavioral decision theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979, 2000; March and Shapira, 1992), we investigate how firm performance and managerial performance aspirations influence the direction and extent of firm strategic repositioning vis-a-vis the firm’s current strategic group in terms of either diverging from or converging to the firm’s current strategic group. Incorporating the role of performance feedback into the analysis of strategic group dynamics seems essential in light of significant performance differences both within and across strategic groups (Cool and Schendel, 1987; McNamara et al., 2003), and the fact that a firm’s current strategic group serves as an important reference point (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Peteraf and Shanley, 1997).

Based on a longitudinal analysis of 1191 US insurance firms and their respective strategic groups between 1999 and 2008, we find that strategic repositioning is largely influenced by how well firms perform in comparison to their strategic group. Thus, the study’s findings support the cognitive and behavioral perspective on strategic groups, suggesting that strategic groups function as performance benchmarks and means of social comparison. In addition, our empirical results suggest that performance aspiration levels have a disparate influence on the decision to either diverge or converge. Performance below aspirations is found to spur managers’ inclination to diverge from group strategy, while the effects of performance above aspirations on strategic repositioning remain ambiguous. The study’s results further show that the influence of performance aspirations on strategic repositioning is contingent on industry factors (i.e., industry dynamism and munificence). We find that dynamism moderates the relationships between performance aspirations and strategic repositioning in a manner that induces convergence, whereas increased levels of munificence induce divergence.

Overall, the study thus contributes to the cognitive and behavioral strand of strategic group research (e.g., Porac and Thomas, 1990; Reger and Huff, 1993). It shifts attention from industry-level towards firm-level determinants of strategic positioning by exploring how firm performance and performance aspirations affect the repositioning choices of firms within strategic group structures. Considering the role of performance feedback, the study delineates the conditions under which firms diverge from their strategic groups from those conditions inducing firm–group convergence. The findings on the influence of performance feedback on firm strategic positioning vis-a-vis their current strategic groups help explain changes in strategic group strategies, changes in group composition, and advance our understanding of strategic group migration paths. The study provides further insights to behavioral theory research on the fundamental question of how aspirations influence firm strategic behavior. Specifically, this is the first study to examine how performance aspirations influence strategic group dynamics. By examining the moderating influence of industry dynamism and munificence, the study further responds to recent calls for a greater consideration of moderators of the aspiration–strategic behavior relationship (Shinkle, 2012).

The remainder of the article is organized as follows. First, we discuss existing conceptualizations of strategic groups and review prior research on strategic group dynamics. Subsequently, we draw on the behavioral theory of the firm to hypothesize how firm performance and performance aspirations influence firms’ strategic repositioning, and integrate industry dynamism and munificence as contingency factors in our theorizing. We then outline our methodological design and present and discuss our results. We conclude with the study’s limitations and implications for theory and practice.

sec.title: Background: Behavioral and cognitive conceptualizations of strategic groups
sec.p: Strategic group research originates from industrial organization (IO) research (Caves and Porter, 1977; Hunt, 1972; Porter, 1979). Therein, strategic groups have been conceptualized as a middle ground between the industry- and firm-level to resolve the conflict between the structure–conduct–performance paradigm, which proposes uniform firm conduct (Bain, 1959; Mason, 1949), and empirical evidence on performance differentials within industries (Bogner et al., 1998). Both the existence of strategic groups and changes in strategic group composition have been explained by the presence of mobility barriers within an industry (Mascarenhas and Aaker, 1989; Porter, 1980). However, in the face of increased criticism regarding IO economics’ basic assumptions, such as uniform firm conduct and equal performance among members of the same strategic group (Barney and Hoskisson, 1990; Hatten and Hatten, 1987), strategic management scholars have reconceptualized the concept of strategic groups. They established a cognitive and behavioral perspective on strategic groups (Bogner et al., 1998), which perceived strategic groups as ‘cognitive communities’ of firms whose managers share a set of beliefs on how to compete and do business in an industry (Porac and Thomas, 1990; Thomas and Carroll, 1994). Within these cognitive communities, managers became characterized as rationally bounded actors that need to simplify their competitive environments by grouping competitors into strategic groups (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Peteraf and Shanley, 1997; Reger and Huff, 1993). For research on strategic group dynamics, the cognitive perspective on strategic groups carried important implications. Contrary to the IO prediction that strategic group dynamics arise from rational managers’ uniform responses to changes in industry conditions, the cognitive perspective on strategic groups proposes that strategic group dynamics accrue from the individual repositioning choices of rationally bounded managers who view strategic groups as important reference points for their decision-making (Baum and Lant, 1995; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Peteraf and Shanley, 1997; Reger and Huff, 1993). The cognitive perspective on strategic groups thus established the idea that social comparison with group members represents an important factor influencing firm positioning within strategic group structures (Bogner, 1991; Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995; Greve, 1998b; Mascarenhas, 1989). Fiegenbaum and Thomas (1995) were among the first to provide empirical support for this idea by showing that firms in the insurance industry continuously benchmark themselves with members of their current strategic group, and utilize strategic group strategy as a reference point when contemplating repositioning. Counter to IO predictions, they also found that firms put little effort in fortifying the mobility barriers that protect their group. Similarly, Bogner et al. (1996) showed that entry points and expansion paths of foreign entrants into the strategic group structure of the US pharmaceutical industry were contingent upon firm resource endowments rather than industry mobility barriers. But despite these findings and growing consent among strategic group researchers that managerial cognition and social comparison largely influence firm positioning within strategic group structures (Bogner et al., 1996; Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995), large-scale quantitative research on these factors has remained scarce. Instead, strategic group research has continued to focus on the influence of industry-level factors on strategic group dynamics.

sec.title: Determinants of strategic positioning within strategic group structures
sec.p: Prior studies have considered various types of structural and environmental discontinuities, such as transitions between industry states or stages, technological innovations, market crises, and regulatory changes as antecedents to strategic group dynamics (McGee and Thomas, 1986; Mascarenhas, 1989; Zuniga-Vicente et al., 2004). Mascarenhas (1989), for example, found that periods of economic growth, stability, and decline differ with respect to how significantly strategic group membership and group strategies change. He found that particularly periods of economic decline induce heterogeneity in firm behavior, and thus imply more frequent changes in group membership and group strategies. Similarly, other studies related the evolution of an industry’s strategic group structure to the industry’s life cycle. Hergert (1988), for instance, found the number of strategic groups to increase with industry maturity due to more differentiated demand structures and technologies which offer a wider set of strategic positioning options for both entrants and incumbents. Conversely, Miles et al. (1993) suggested that industry maturity may in fact lead to a reduced number of strategic groups. They argued that with increased industry maturity incumbents shift their focus from product market differentiation to production efficiency, leading to greater similarity among firms and thus fewer strategic groups. Other studies focused on industry events rather than life cycle stages to explain strategic group dynamics (MásRuíz, 1999; Zuniga-Vicente et al., 2004). They showed that environmental discontinuities induce heterogeneity in firm strategies (e.g., Chattopadhyay et al., 2001) and thus promote repositioning of firms that lead to new strategic groups, increased inter-group mobility, and shifts in performance differences between groups (e.g., Zuniga-Vicente et al., 2004).

Even though most of these studies build their arguments on the individual behavior of firms, they assume that strategic group dynamics are merely prompted by changes in industry conditions and shocks. Counter to this firm-exogenous explanation, we propose that intra- and inter-group mobility and thus shifts in strategic group strategy predominantly accrue from managers’ performance aspirations. Our reasoning is grounded on the behavioral theory of the firm (Cyert and March, 1963; Simon, 1957) and behavioral decision theory (e.g., Kahneman and Tversky, 1979; March and Shapira, 1992). It directly ties into the cognitive and behavioral conceptualization of strategic groups (e.g., Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995; Porac et al., 1989) and explicates how performance and performance aspirations induce managers to reposition their firms within their industry’s strategic group structure by either diverging from or converging to their strategic groups.

sec.title: Strategic divergence–convergence relative to the current strategic group
sec.p: Within an industry’s strategic group structure, managers perceive their current strategic group as their key referent (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995), what gives them two opposing options in repositioning their firm. The first option is to reposition the firm in a manner that renders it less similar to its current strategic group but more similar to adjacent strategic groups. The second option is to reposition in a manner that makes the firm more similar to its current strategic group. We use the concept of ‘strategic divergence–convergence’ to capture these opposing directions of repositioning in one single measure. It expresses for each firm and year both the direction and extent of firm strategic repositioning vis-a-vis its current strategic group.

Using each firm’s current strategic group as reference object sets this study apart from prior research on strategic divergence–convergence, which applied a dyadic firm-to-firm operationalization including all firms in the industry as managerial reference objects (i.e., Park, 2007). This important difference with respect to the reference object not only results from our research focus on strategic groups, but is also due to theoretical and methodological reasons. Theoretically, an all firm encompassing dyadic approach is inconsistent with the view of managers as rationally bounded actors in behavioral theory (Cyert and March, 1963; Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995; Porac and Thomas, 1994). In the case of our research, which is based on a comprehensive sample of 1191 firms, the dyadic approach, for instance, would assume that a firm’s executive management benchmarks its firm every year with 1190 competitors when considering repositioning. This not only conflicts with managers’ bounded rationality and firms’ resource constraints but is also inconsistent with the well-established finding that managers segment their firms’ rivals into groups of relevant and less relevant competitors (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Porac and Thomas, 1994). The failure of the dyadic approach to differentiate between these relevant and less relevant competitors also raises methodological concerns. The dyadic approach implies that all firm–competitor relationships are equally considered, which leads to confounded results as a large number of these relationships are in reality not part of managers’ sense-making and decision-making processes.

Following our conceptualization of strategic divergence–convergence, a firm diverges when its strategic profile becomes more dissimilar to the strategic profile of its current strategic group and converges when the profiles become more similar. We operationalize both firm and strategic group strategic profiles as positioning vectors in an n-dimensional ‘strategic space’ (Mehra and Floyd, 1998) which is characterized by dimensions that reflect the typical scope and resource deployment decisions of US insurance firms (i.e., customer/product scope, product diversity, firm size, production efficiency, reinsurance/investment strategy) (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1990). If we denote a focal firm i’s positioning vector at time t–Δ as Xi,t–Δ and its respective strategic group’s vector as XSG(i), t–Δ, and both positioning vectors change over the time period Δ as the firm and its strategic group change their positioning, the distance between the firm and the strategic group will change too. This change in distance is reflected in our strategic divergence–convergence measure (SDC). If the measure assumes a negative value, the firm has diverged from the center of its strategic group; if the measure assumes a positive value, instead, the firm has converged towards the center of its strategic group. sec.title: The effects of performance, aspirations, and behavioral biases on strategic divergence–convergence
sec.p: Firm repositioning is a function of various industry, group, and firm characteristics. In contrast to prior research which has focused on industry characteristics as determinants of strategic repositioning within strategic group structures (e.g., Cool and Schendel, 1987; Mascarenhas, 1989; Zuniga-Vicente et al., 2004), this study shifts attention to firm characteristics. Drawing on insights from behavioral theory, we focus on firm performance and performance aspirations as determinants of strategic repositioning, before integrating industry dynamism and munificence as contingency factors in our theorizing. Figure 2 provides an overview of our research framework.

caption.p: PRA+ = Performance above aspirations; PRA - = Performance below aspirations.

sec.p: The behavioral theory of the firm suggests firm performance as a central firm-level determinant of strategic repositioning (Audia and Greve, 2006; Cyert and March, 1963; Greve, 1998a; Levitt and March, 1988). The theory argues that managers initiate organizational search processes, dubbed as ‘problemistic search’, when firm performance falls short of the goals the managers have set for the firm. These search processes aim at returning performance to satisfying levels through improving current business practices and strategies. In search of better practices and strategies, managers usually first scan the business environment in close proximity to the firm’s current positioning (Cyert and March, 1963). Yet, when performance problems increase, managers were found to engage in more extensive and complex search processes (Cyert and March, 1963; Levinthal and March, 1981).

In industries where firms can be grouped in spatially distributed clusters characterized by similar strategic characteristics and practices, such a performance-induced variation in search scopes impacts the direction and extent of firm repositioning. Narrow search scopes, as implied by minor performance problems, suggest that managers will try to improve firm performance by adopting strategies and practices by members of the firm’s current strategic group, or by members of adjacent groups in close proximity (Cyert and March, 1963; Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995; Greve, 1998b; Huff, 1982). Wider search scopes, as implied by more severe performance problems, instead, make managers more likely adopt practices and strategies by members of more ‘distant’ strategic groups (Cyert and March, 1963; Greve, 1998b; Mascarenhas and Aaker, 1989; Porac et al., 1989). By adopting more distant practices uncommon or unknown within the extant strategic group, firms will diverge from their current strategic group and its group strategy.

While performance shortfalls trigger either local or distant search processes, satisfactory or even superior financial performance has been found to affect managerial behavior distinctively differently. If firms perform well, their managers are expected to take status quo preserving measures and to avoid actions that might negatively influence performance (Audia et al., 2000; Bromiley et al., 2001; Cyert and March, 1963). Superior firm performance has further been found to lead to an increased tendency by managers to repeat those competitive actions and strategies to which they attribute past successes, irrespective of whether such a causal link exists (Levitt and March, 1988; Miller and Chen, 1994, 1996; Milliken and Lant, 1991). Taken together, these effects make high-performing firms’ strategic behavior more predictable and thus easier to imitate (Miller, 1994; Walsh, 1995). This is important since high-performing firms generally tend to be imitated by rivals. Specifically, social and economic theories of imitation suggest that managers perceive performance as an important indicator for the viability of market positions and business practices (Bikhchandani et al., 1992; Greve, 1998b; Haveman, 1993; Lieberman and Asaba, 2006; Mansfield, 1961). Imitation by rivals has an important implication for the strategic positioning of high-performing firms within strategic groups: it turns strategic group strategy more similar to the firms’ strategies and thus moves better performing firms into the centers of their current strategic groups (DiMaggio and Powell, 1983; Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1995).

In sum, the broader search scopes of low-performing firms suggests that low-performing firms diverge from their strategic groups. In contrast, inertia of success in high-performing firms coupled with a general inclination of rival firms to imitate high-performing firms makes high-performing firms converge towards the center of their current strategic groups. We therefore propose:

HYPOTHESIS 1: A focal firm’s performance positively relates to its strategic divergence–convergence. Low-performing firms diverge from their current strategic groups, high-performing firms converge towards their current strategic groups.

Hypothesis 1 proposes a general relationship between firm performance and the direction of a firm’s strategic repositioning vis-a-vis its current strategic group, with low performance inducing divergence, and high performance inducing convergence (see dashed line AB in Figure 3). However, the above theoretical reasoning does not yet specify the performance level that discriminates ‘low’ from ‘high’ performance, raising the critical question where the inflection point between divergence and convergence actually lies. The behavioral theory of the firm may hold an answer to this question. It suggests that managerial aspirations, defined as the desired performance level held by management (Cyert and March, 1963), mark the borderline between what managers perceive as failure and success, and thus influence firm’s search behavior (Bromiley, 1991; Cyert and March, 1963; Greve, 1998a, 2003). Central to our subsequent theoretical reasoning is that deviations from the aspiration level give rise to behavioral biases which further specify the relationship proposed in Hypothesis 1.

In firms that perform below managerial aspirations, managers have been found to increasingly select new strategies to improve performance (e.g., Bromiley, 1991; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Shinkle, 2012). These new strategies are assumed to involve greater risk (Bromiley, 1991). According to the behavioral theory of the firm, managers generally engage in increased risk taking if performance falls short of aspirations because they feel the need to improve firm performance through bolder actions (Audia and Greve, 2006; Cyert and March, 1992). Further, prospect theory provides an alternative explanation for greater risk taking below aspirations (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979, 2000). It argues that humans give greater weight to losses and thus assess decision options based on the question how many losses the different options may recover. Due to this negative framing, humans were found to prefer gambles over choices with certain outcomes, implying risk seeking (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979, 2000).

Both the behavioral theory of the firm and prospect theory as part of behavioral decision theory thus predict increased risk taking in form of the selection and adoption of new practices and strategies for firms that perform below aspirations. Overall, these additional theoretical arguments derived from the behavioral theory of the firm and prospect theory suggest that performance shortfalls from the aspiration level imply even greater inclinations to diverge than suggested by our earlier arguments.

For firms performing above managerial aspirations, behavioral and prospect theory would instead principally predict more risk-averse behavior, and thus greater convergence. Several studies, however, have shown that performance above aspirations can in fact lead to higher risk taking and change (e.g., Chen and Miller, 2007). This counterintuitive finding has been explained by the limited threat of falling below aspirations (Bromiley et al., 2001). In addition, behavioral decision theory provides an alternative explanation for increased risk taking by managers of firms that perform above managerial aspirations. It has been argued and found that managers of firms performing above aspirations become subject to the self-attribution bias (Shefrin, 1999), which means that managers will attribute their firm’s success primarily to their own superior abilities and disregard other potential explanatory factors, such as external conditions (Clapham and Schwenk, 1991; Kelley and Michela, 1980). As a consequence, managerial self-confidence increases, potentially further propelled by positive media coverage or a natural disposition of the involved managers (i.e., a high level of self-efficacy [Bandura, 1977], or narcissism). This process, which may culminate in managerial hubris, affects managerial risk taking through inducing an aversion to comprehensive decision processes and turning decision-makers less sensitive to risks (Chatterjee and Hambrick, 2007; Hayward and Hambrick, 1997; Levinthal and March, 1993; Van Velsor and Leslie, 1995). Increased managerial risk taking leading to greater strategic divergence for firms performing above aspirations is further facilitated by the fact that superior performance increases CEO discretion and limits board vigilance (e.g., Boyd, 1994; Daily and Johnson, 1997; Golden and Zajac, 2001). In line with this theoretical argument, Haynes and Hillman (2010) recently found that CEO power positively relates to a firm’s strategic divergence from industry norms.

Collectively, these theoretical and empirical insights suggest that in firms performing above aspirations managers are subject to conflicting forces of both subdued and heightened risk taking. Regardless of how these conflicting forces play out in firms that perform above managerial aspirations, we can conclude that divergent strategies are more common in both firms performing below and above aspirations than suggested by the initial arguments leading to Hypothesis 1. Integrating this insight into our theorizing turns the linear relationship presented earlier (see dashed line AB in Figure 3) into a kinked-curve relationship with a structural break at the aspiration level (see solid line COD in Figure 3). Hence, we propose:
HYPOTHESIS 2: Performance below aspirations is more positively related to strategic divergence–convergence than performance above aspirations.

sec.title: The moderating influence of industry dynamism and munificence
sec.p: So far, we proposed that firm repositioning is a function of firm performance and managerial performance aspirations, which are associated with several behavioral biases (e.g., risk seeking, overconfidence bias). In the following paragraphs, we discuss how the industry environment, as a central source of strategic group dynamics (e.g., Fiegenbaum et al., 2001; Mascarenhas, 1989), impacts the theoretical logic which we have proposed. We characterize the industry environment along its key dimensions industry dynamism and munificence.

Industry dynamism represents the degree of instability and uncertainty within an industry (Dess and Beard, 1984; Duncan, 1972). Increased levels of instability and uncertainty make it much more difficult for managers to discern and predict patterns and regularities (Eisenhardt and Bourgeois, 1988; Gort, 1969; Hrebiniak and Joyce, 1985). Due to greater uncertainty, managers further suffer from greater information processing burdens and experience higher levels of stress and anxiety (Tushman, 1979; Waldman et al., 2001). Together, these effects suggest that the degree of industry dynamism is likely to affect managers’ search behavior, risk taking, and confidence, which have been argued to lead to disparate choices regarding firm repositioning for firms performing below and for firms performing above aspirations.

For firms performing below aspirations, we proposed two reasons for firms’ inclination to diverge. First, we argued that performance shortfalls induce managers to widen their search scopes to seek more innovative solutions for their firms’ performance problems (Cyert and March, 1963). Second, we proposed based on the behavioral theory of the firm that attainment discrepancies induce risk seeking in form of the selection of new, divergent firm strategies (Cyert and March, 1963; Kahnemann and Tversky, 1979). An increase in industry dynamism interferes with both of these arguments since it asymmetrically impacts the risk-return profiles of divergent and convergent firm strategies. Despite its adverse effect on the predictability of any decision outcome, increases in industry dynamism particularly disfavor more risky choices (Dess and Beard, 1984; Duncan, 1972). Given their wider initial payoff-distribution, divergent choices imply larger absolute risk increases under conditions of heightened industry dynamism. This effect renders the adoption of business practices and strategies that are new to a firm more unfavorable. When faced with increased industry dynamism, managers will acknowledge this adverse effect and expand their search scopes more reluctantly. Similarly, the risk-seeking behavior of managers is affected as managers will likely factor in that divergent strategies have become more risky. In other words, industry dynamism itself puts a strain on the risk tolerance of managers (Li and Simerly, 1998; Smart and Vertinsky, 1984). Taken together, these risk-related effects of industry dynamism dampen the relationship between performance and strategic divergence below the aspiration level.

In contrast, for firms performing above aspirations, the relationship between performance and strategic divergence–convergence is likely to be positively moderated by industry dynamism. Social and economic theories of imitation suggest that under conditions of increased uncertainty, managers are more willing to discard their own private information and to increasingly rely on rival behavior in informing their decisions. Similarly, social comparison theory (Festinger, 1950: 273) proposes that when there is a lack of ‘physical reality … to validate the own opinion or belief’, social referents become more important. In line with these theoretical predictions, managers of poor performing firms have been argued and found to increase their efforts to mimic better performing rival firms under conditions of increased uncertainty (Greve, 1998b; Haunschild and Miner, 1997; Lieberman and Asaba, 2006). By propelling performance-based imitation, industry dynamism thus spurs the convergence of high-performing firms towards the centers of their strategic groups.

Additionally, theoretical predictions by social psychology research suggest a dampening effect of industry dynamism on the mechanisms leading to managerial overconfidence. Self-attribution theory suggests that self-serving behavior and overconfidence become less likely when there is a good chance that others may challenge or contradict the managers’ claim of being responsible for the positive firm results (Snyder et al., 1976). In dynamic environments which are characterized by unpredictable changes, stakeholders (e.g., investors) are likely to become more critically aware of the fact that firm performance cannot be solely attributed to managers’ skills, but is to a considerable extent a manifestation of a firm’s good fortune and luck (Barney, 1986). Managerial overconfidence (or even hubris) is thus likely to be reduced under conditions of increased industry dynamism.

Following the above reasoning, we conclude that industry dynamism moderates the relationship between performance and strategic divergence–convergence both below and above the aspiration level such that inclinations to diverge become reduced. This effect renders the proposed kink in the relationship between performance relative to aspirations and strategic divergence–convergence less pronounced (see solid line COD in Figure 3).

HYPOTHESIS 3a/b: Industry dynamism moderates the relationship between performance and strategic divergence–convergence such that convergence becomes more likely. This implies a negative moderation below the aspiration level (3a), and a positive moderation above the aspiration level (3b).

Managerial risk taking and search behavior, however, are not only influenced by the level of uncertainty but also by the level of resource availability. Munificent industries are characterized by an abundance of resources, reduced resource dependencies, and greater opportunities for profitable firm growth (e.g., Dess and Beard, 1984; Duncan, 1972; Staw and Szwajkowski, 1975). Yet, these growth opportunities are not uniformly distributed throughout the industry. Individual segments contribute to the industry’s overall growth to different degrees (Harberger, 1998; Levinthal, 1997; Schumpeter, 1939). An uneven distribution of growth, however, implies a multi-peaked growth-landscape, which can be better searched with broader search strategies (Gavetti and Levinthal, 2000).

For firms that perform below managerial aspirations, which have broader search scopes and an increased propensity for risk taking, this means that they hold an advantage under these conditions (Brittain and Freeman, 1980; Miller and Chen, 1994). Further, industry munificence reduces resource constraints and lowers rivalry-based mobility barriers since market leaders less forcefully defend their market segments against new entrants and existing rivals (e.g., Miller and Chen, 1994). As a consequence, divergent strategies become less costly and imply fewer risks than under more resource-scarce conditions (Carroll et al., 1994). Complementary to our earlier argument that industry dynamism negatively impacts the risk-return profile of strategically divergent behavior, this leaves us to conclude that munificent conditions, in contrast, positively influence the risk-return profile of divergent behavior for firms below aspirations.

For firms that perform above aspirations, there are two major reasons for why the propensity for divergent strategic behavior may become more pronounced under conditions of industry munificence. First, the lower mobility barriers under conditions of industry munificence make strategic group migration less costly and risky. Overconfident managers are thus even less likely to shy away from efforts to migrate to more dissimilar groups. Second, under conditions of abundant resources and diminished resource dependency, stakeholders are likely to exercise less stringent oversight. The greater discretion further facilitates the adoption of bold divergent strategies of risk-seeking managers (Gomez, 2004).

In sum, we thus propose that industry munificence amplifies the effects of risk seeking and self-attribution on the relationship between performance relative to aspirations and strategic divergence–convergence. The proposed kink within the relationship (see solid line COD in Figure 3) thereby becomes more pronounced, indicating that the overall tendency to diverge from the current strategic group increases. We thus hypothesize:

HYPOTHESIS 4a/b: Industry munificence moderates the relationship between performance and strategic divergence–convergence such that divergence becomes more likely. This implies a positive moderation below the aspiration level (4a), and a negative moderation above the aspiration level (4b).

sec.title: Research setting
sec.p: Mehra and Floyd assert that an industry needs to meet two requirements in order to provide sufficient ‘strategic space’ for accommodating strategic groups: ‘(a) The viable positions within the industry [must] be sufficiently heterogeneous to allow for differentiation along the dimensions of group strategies and (b) … some or all of the resources underlying the shared strategies [must] be inimitable’ (1998: 512). Our empirical analyses are set in the US insurance industry, an industry that offers a high degree of product market heterogeneity in combination with differing resource requirements for the distinct market positions. With respect to products, insurers can design their mix of service offerings by choosing from property and liability (P&L) and life insurance products. Within both product categories, various customer risks can be insured, either with focus on private or commercial customers (Grace and Barth, 1993). In total, these dimensions segment the industry into more than 40 distinct lines of business (A.M. Best, 2009). Since the risks insured in different lines of business vary regarding their duration and magnitude, the legal (capital) requirements vary as well. Furthermore, the operational processes of risk assessment, pooling, pricing, claims management, and litigation differ, requiring firms to develop resources and skills tailored to their offerings. While some regulators restrict firms from combining Life and P&L products, US regulators have always allowed firms to freely decide on their products (Berger et al., 2000). In addition to the wide range of viable market positions, the very active market for corporate control and the vast size and non-monolithic character of the US insurance industry provide ideal conditions for strategic group formation (A.M. Best, 2009; Berger et al., 2000; Grace and Barth, 1993).

sec.title: Sample and data
sec.p: Our study sets itself apart from prior research in terms of overall sample size and sampling timeframe. In contrast to prior strategic group research, which rarely studied more than 100 firms and only small fractions of the respective industries (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1990, 1995; Houthoofd and Heene, 1997; McNamara et al., 2003; Osborne et al., 2001), our sample includes 1191 firms, representing more than 75% of the US insurance industry in any year – both in terms of gross premiums written and number of market incumbents. The sample closely reflects the composition of the US insurance industry (Mayers and Smith, 1988; Smith and Stutzer, 1995). We examine the strategic repositioning of these firms in the time period from 1999 to 2008, during which the industry’s regulatory frame remained fairly stable, whereas the industry’s competitive environment offered sufficient variation in our independent variables. Firm data were drawn from A.M. Best’s Global File statement, the most comprehensive source of firm and financial data for the insurance industry (Katrishen and Scordis, 1998). Capital market and industry data were drawn from COMPUSTAT and Swiss Re Sigma Research (Swiss Re, 2008).

sec.title: Identification of strategic group structure
sec.p: An accurate identification of strategic groups must be based on measures that are critical to the specific industry under study (Mascarenhas, 1989; Short et al., 2007). Our selection of measures builds on prior strategic group research within the US insurance industry (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1990, 1995), and includes factors pertaining to decisions about firm scope and resource deployment. Based on discussions with industry experts, we only made a minor adjustment to the established set of measures by substituting the net premiums written by gross premiums written, because it is generally the gross written premiums that mark an insurance firm’s position within its product markets.

In deriving the strategic groups, we then combined the strengths of qualitative (social constructivist) and quantitative approaches to strategic group identification. Following prior research’s advice (Diesing, 1971; Jick, 1979), we used the qualitative interpretation of industry experts to inform a subsequent quantitative research design drawing on archival sources (Reger and Huff, 1993). Specifically, we asked industry experts to provide us with their cognitive groups of the industry, which we then used to condition a clustering algorithm so that it was able to produce an industry structure that reflected the experts’ perceptions of the industry’s strategic group structure on a larger scale. Following prior classification research (DeSarbo et al., 1984; De Soete, 1986; Huh and Lim, 2009; Vichi and Kiers, 2001), we conditioned the clustering algorithm by assigning weights to the clustering variables before using them in k-means clustering.1 We derived the variable weights for our clustering variables based on Makarenkov and Legendre (2001a, 2001b). The algorithm underlying this step minimizes a loss function (LP) through finding variable weights (w) that minimize the sums of within-group squared distances to the cluster centroids (dij2) of all clusters (k). nk denotes the total number of firms within cluster k:

Since the validity of our subsequent clustering depends on the quality of the variable weights derived by the optimization procedure described above, we paid special attention to surveying the initial clusters the procedure required as input. Specifically, we chose the full context form of the repertory grid technique, which is particularly suited to elicit similarity judgments (Fransella and Bannister, 1977; Kelly, 1955; Spencer et al., 2003; Tan and Hunter, 2002), to survey the cognitive groups of the participating industry experts. This technique requires research participants to sort a pool of elements into any number of discrete sets based on whatever similarity criteria they chose. Following Milligan (1996), we asked 12 top managers from five different global insurance firms to independently choose 40 ‘ideal type’ firms well-known to them and to sort these firms into groups. Conforming with Reger and Huff’s proposition that the perception of a ‘strategic group structure will be widely shared by strategists within an industry’ (1993: 106), we received very similar cluster solutions from the industry experts. They contained a total of 94 different firms and were structured in four to six clusters. As each of these 12 cluster solutions implied a slightly different set of variable weights, we used the arithmetic means of the weights in the further process of this study.

Using these variable weights, we extrapolated the industry experts’ cognitive maps of their chosen ‘ideal type’ firms to all 1191 firms in the sample and over the full 10-year range through standard cluster analysis, as described by Ketchen and Shook (1996). As the number of strategic groups likely reflects our industry experts’ most recent perceptions of the industry structure, we used statistical stopping rules to determine how many strategic groups were present in every year of the study period (Everitt, 1980; Milligan, 1996; Milligan and Cooper, 1985; Sneath and Sokal, 1973). Specifically, we applied the Calinski and Harabasz (1974) pseudo-F test and Duda and Hart’s (1973) Je(2)/Je(1) index to the 3- to 12-cluster solutions of all years produced by two-stage clustering involving hierarchical (Ward’s method) and non-hierarchical (k-means) methods. Both stopping rules recommended five cluster solutions in all years, which we then produced through k-means clustering.

We validated this 10-year cluster solution through several means. First, we assessed the similarity of our clusters (particularly the most recent ones) with those provided by the industry experts. This means we searched for the 94 ‘ideal type’ firms chosen by the industry experts within the cluster solution analytically derived, and found the firms to be assigned to groups very similar to the clusters initially provided by the industry experts. We further reviewed our final cluster solution for descriptive validity (McNamara et al., 2003; Thomas and Venkatraman, 1988) and found it to discriminate well between P&L and Life insurers, two naturally occurring groups within the insurance industry (Nair and Kotha, 2001), as well as between firms that focus on private or corporate customers.

sec.title: Strategic divergence–convergence
sec.p: With reference to its current strategic group, a firm’s repositioning takes either the form of divergence or convergence. Similar to prior research (Carroll et al., 1994; Chen and Hambrick, 1995; Cool and Dierickx, 1993; Gimeno and Woo, 1996; Park, 2007), we assess a firm’s degree of divergence or convergence with a variable that quantifies the strategic distance a firm has covered in a distinct year vis-a-vis its current strategic group. We calculate the distance covered as the change in firm and strategic group positions within the industry. Since the dimensions of the US insurance industry’s strategic space (i.e., customer/product scope, product diversity, firm size, production efficiency, reinsurance/investment strategy) (Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1990, 1995) are not orthogonal (i.e., they correlate) and have different ranges, we calculate Mahalanobis (1936) distances instead of Euclidean distances (Hair et al., 2009). Formally, our operationalization of ‘strategic divergence–convergence’ (SDC) reads as:

In this equation, SDCi,g,t expresses the strategic distance covered by firm i in year t with reference to strategic group g of which the firm was a member at t-1. Xi,t is the n-sized multivariate vector holding the values of the strategic dimensions that characterize firm i at the end of year t. µg,t represents the mean values of these variables as defined by the strategic group g. S denotes the covariance matrix of the variables included in the vectors. Following this definition, SDCi,g,t takes on a negative value if the firm has diverged from its strategic group during the course of year t, and a positive value if the firm has converged towards its strategic group.

sec.title: Performance relative to aspirations
sec.p: Performance relative to aspirations is defined as the differential between a firm’s performance and aspiration level. Similar to prior research, we operationalize the firm aspiration level based on social and historical components (e.g., Bromiley, 1991; Cyert and March, 1963; Herriot et al., 1985; Park, 2007; Wiseman and Bromiley, 1996). Yet, the composition in which social and historical factors define aspirations is largely unclear (Shinkle, 2012). Research thus suggests an ‘in situ’ operationalization driven by the research context (Shinkle, 2012: 417). Following this advice, we draw on research closest to our arguments (i.e., strategic group research and research on the role of external referents) and concur with its view that a firm’s current strategic group marks a firm’s central performance benchmark and thus defines its aspiration level unless the firm already performs better than its group (e.g., Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Ketchen and Palmer, 1999; Lehner, 2000; Park, 2007). We thus construe a firm’s aspiration level based on the average performance level of the firm’s current strategic group, and on the firm’s own historical performance if it performs better than its current strategic group. In the latter case, we raise the firm’s past performance by a small factor that accounts for firms’ general ambition to improve2 (Bromiley, 1991; Deephouse and Wiseman, 2000). Hence, our operationalization of performance relative to aspirations (PRA) reads as follows:

Pi,t denotes the performance level of firm i at time t, while SGPi,t represents the performance level of the firm’s current strategic group. Similar to other research on insurance firms (e.g., BarNiv and McDonald, 1992; Elango, 2009), we assess firm financial performance as return on assets (ROA) operationalized as net income before extraordinary items and preferred dividends divided by total assets. We distinguish between the effects of performance below and above aspirations by piecewise regression models using a linear spline function for PRA with a knot at zero, and separate the individual splines using the mkspline command of STATA 11.

sec.title: Industry dynamism and munificence
sec.p: To assess industry dynamism, we use an industry-specific operationalization, the total insured catastrophe losses incurred. The measure quantifies the severity of market events and shocks that hit the US insurance industry and thus proxies the uncertainties managers faced at specific points of time. For the analyzed year range, two market shocks stand out: the terrorist attacks of 11 September 2001, and Hurricane Katrina in late August 2005. While being mainly perceived as human tragedies of unprecedented size, both events also represented major economic shocks, particularly to the US insurance industry (Born and Viscusi, 2006; Chen et al., 2008). As for industry munificence, we follow prior research (Dess and Beard, 1984; Staw and Szwajkowski, 1975; Yasai-Ardekani, 1989) and use the industry’s growth rate to measure the degree of industry munificence. We calculated the industry’s growth rate based on the total market volume (i.e., the total gross premiums written) of the combined US P&C and Life markets, as provided in the A.M. Best Global File Statement (A.M. Best, 2009).

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: To rule out alternative explanations for our results, we control for several factors at the firm-, strategic group-, and industry-level. All control variables are lagged by one period. At the firm-level, we control for firm size using the natural logarithm of gross premiums written. Further, we control for firm slack, measured as the quick ratio, which is calculated as quick assets3 divided by net liabilities plus ceded reinsurance balances payable (A.M. Best, 2009). Important for studies in the insurance industry (Augustine, 1998; Group of Thirty, 2006), we further control for the reinsurance strategy of firms. Since insurance firms can transfer parts of their business and the associated risks to reinsurers, they can strategically vary their volume of business and risk exposure, which has an impact on how the firm is affected by environmental uncertainty. Similar to prior research, we control for firms’ reinsurance strategies by their ‘ceded portions’ (Augustine, 1998), which is calculated as the absolute amount of premiums transferred to reinsurers divided by the gross premiums written. The inclination to diverge or converge is further likely to be influenced by the degree to which a firm’s strategy is dissimilar to the average strategic profile of its group (Finkelstein and Hambrick, 1990). We operationalize the degree of strategic dissimilarity by means of Mahalanobis (1936) distance measures, scaling a firm’s strategic distance to the strategic group’s center by the average strategic distance.

We further include control variables at the strategic group-level. Given varying internal structures of strategic groups (Ketchen et al., 1993; McNamara et al., 2003; Reger and Huff, 1993), we control for the strength of the strategic group’s core (Hergert, 1988). The variable indicates the proportion of firms that closely identify with their strategic group’s strategy and thus expresses (a) how strongly the strategic group works as a benchmark to its members, and (b) whether the group’s core is already highly populated, impacting the member firms’ motivation to diverge or converge. We operationalize the variable as the proportion of a strategic group’s core firms (McNamara et al., 2003) located in a circle around the group’s center with a radius equal to one-third of the maximum distance any member firm is located away from the group’s center. We control for strategic group concentration since intense rivalry may positively relate to the firms’ inclinations to abandon prior market positions (Hawley, 1950). We measure the overall dispersion of firms within strategic groups through Herfindahl indices. Specifically, we calculated each strategic group’s Herfindahl index by adding up the squared proportions of member firms located in 10 subspaces of the strategic space the group occupies (Mehra and Floyd, 1998). To control for mimetic behavior, we further add a variable that measures the ratio of diverging firms for each strategic group. Due to a lack of reliable information on the risks and benefits of adopting new practices and strategies, managers might be inclined to mimic their firms’ peer rivals when contemplating strategic change, particularly if rivals reposition in a coherent manner (Bikhchandani et al., 1992; DiMaggio and Powell, 1983; Mansfield, 1961). We operationalize this variable as the proportion of firms that have diverged from the strategic group in the preceding year. Additionally, we include strategic group dummies in our analysis, parceling out time-invariant group-level characteristics, such as the varying heights of mobility barriers (Mascarenhas and Aaker, 1989).

At the industry-level, we control for industry concentration. Consistent with prior research (Cool and Dierickx, 1993; Ordover et al., 1982), we use the industry Herfindahl index to measure industry concentration. We calculate the index for each year by adding up the squared value of the individual market shares of all firms in the US insurance industry.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: For our empirical analysis, we applied fixed effects panel regression analysis. We refrained from cross-sectionally pooling data over different stable strategic time periods (e.g., Cool and Schendel, 1987) since it hinders an uninterrupted study of firm-level behavior and produces statistical noise (DeSarbo et al., 2009; Fuente-Sabaté et al., 2007). A fixed rather than a random effects model was used based on results of a Hausman specification test (Hausman, 1978).

sec.title: Strategic groups, their performance implications, and influence on strategic positioning
sec.p: Throughout the study period, our analyses suggest three strategic groups of firms focusing on Life insurance products (strategic groups 1, 2, and 5), and two strategic groups of firms focusing on P&L products (strategic groups 3 and 4). While the composition of the strategic groups changed depending on the extent of strategic repositioning of the firms in our sample, the number of strategic groups remained stable over our study period. Figure 4 illustrates the performance levels of the different strategic groups over the study period. The performance levels shown significantly differ from each other in all years (p < .001), which underscores the general relevance of studying strategic repositioning and strategic group dynamics.

sec.p: Values for our dependent variable ‘strategic divergence–convergence’ range from −4.96 to +4.90, with a mean of 0.02 and a standard deviation of 0.61 (p < .001). The mean value of 0.02 suggests that the sampled firms, on average, slightly converge towards rather than diverge from their current strategic group. The high correlation between firm performance and performance above/below aspirations does not cause problems of multicollinearity since these variables are not used in the same models. To further examine whether multicollinearity was present, we ran standard OLS regression analysis with firm dummies included in order to calculate the variance inflation factors (VIF) for the variables in each model. The mean of the variance inflation factors ranged from 1.97 to 2.53, while the maximum variance inflation factor was 6.60. With no values near the rule-of-thumb cutoff of 10 (Neter et al., 1985), multicollinearity does not seem to affect our results.

Table 2 shows the results of our fixed effects time series regression analysis. When interpreting regression coefficients in our models, it needs to be considered that our dependent variable ‘strategic divergence–convergence’ takes on negative values if firms diverge from their current strategic groups, and positive values if they converge towards their current strategic groups. This means that a negative regression coefficient in Table 2 implies that an increase of the specific variable increases a firm’s inclination to diverge from its current strategic group. A positive regression coefficient, on the contrary, implies that an increase of the variable increases the focal firm’s inclination to converge towards its current strategic group.

sec.p: Model 1 is the control model and indicates that increases in strategic group concentration (b = −0.60, p < .05) and the ratio of diverging firms (b = −0.74, p < .001) negatively relate to the extent of a firm’s strategic convergence towards its group. In contrast, we find a positive impact of both the strength of the group’s core (b = 0.32, p < .01) and a firm’s strategic dissimilarity (b = 1.73, p < .001) on the extent of strategic divergence–convergence.

Hypothesis 1 predicted that a focal firm’s financial performance (PRA) positively relates to the extent of a firm’s strategic divergence–convergence towards its group. As shown in Model 2, the coefficient of the firm performance variable is positive and significant (b = 0.6, p < .05), supporting Hypothesis 1.

Hypothesis 2 further specified this relationship by suggesting that performance variations below the aspiration level imply greater variations in strategic divergence–convergence than above the aspiration level. Model 3 introduces individual regression splines for performance below (PRA–) and performance above (PRA+) aspirations. The coefficient of PRA– is positive and significant (b = 1.85, p < .001), providing support for the proposition that firms which perform below aspirations tend to diverge from the centers of their strategic groups. Instead, the coefficient of PRA+ is found to be slightly negative and insignificant. Taken together, the coefficients provide evidence for a kink of the regression line at the aspiration level and thus for Hypothesis 2.4 The larger size of the PRA– coefficient in comparison to the PRA coefficient in Model 2 suggests that particularly firms that perform below their managers’ aspiration levels diverge more strongly from their strategic groups than initially assumed.

Hypothesis 3a proposed that industry dynamism negatively moderates the relationship between performance below aspirations and strategic divergence–convergence, while Hypothesis 3b proposed that industry dynamism positively moderates the relationship between performance above aspirations and strategic divergence–convergence. The proposed negative moderation of dynamism for performance below aspirations implies a flattening of the left regression spline (line CO in Figure 3), whereas the proposed positive moderation of dynamism for performance above aspirations suggests an increase in the right spline’s slope (line OD in Figure 3). Both effects reflect a trend towards greater convergence under conditions of dynamism. Model 4 shows that the interaction term between industry dynamism and performance below aspirations is negative and significant (b = −0.53, p < .10) while the interaction term between industry dynamism and performance above aspirations is positive and significant (b = 0.73, p < .05). Hypotheses 3a/b are thus supported by our empirical results.

Hypothesis 4a suggested that industry munificence positively moderates the relationship between PRA– and strategic divergence–convergence while Hypothesis 4b proposed a negative moderation effect for the relationship between PRA+ and strategic divergence–convergence. In graphical terms, these moderation effects suggest an increase in steepness of the regression spline below the aspiration level (line CO in Figure 3), as well as a further bending down of the regression spline above the aspiration level (OD in Figure 3). Both changes reflect trends towards greater strategic divergence. Model 5 supports both predictions with the interaction term between performance below aspirations and munificence being positive and significant (b = 25.60, p < .05), and the interaction term between performance above aspirations and munificence being negative and significant (b = −24.63, p < .001).

sec.title: Discussion and implications
sec.p: The present study investigates the behavioral mechanisms driving the strategic repositioning of firms within and across strategic groups. It reveals how the interplay of firm-, group-, and industry-level characteristics prompts changes in firm positioning and thus in strategic group membership and average strategic group strategies. Drawing on the behavioral theory of the firm (Cyert and March, 1963) and behavioral decision theory (e.g., Kahneman and Tversky, 1979, 2000; March and Shapira, 1992), the study investigates how firm performance and managerial performance aspirations influence the direction and extent of firm strategic repositioning vis-a-vis the firm’s current strategic group. Such a theoretical integration of performance feedback into strategic group dynamics appears particularly important in light of significant performance differences both within and across strategic groups (Cool and Schendel, 1987; McNamara et al., 2003), and the fact that a firm’s current strategic group serves as an important reference point for its strategic repositioning (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Peteraf and Shanley, 1997; Reger and Huff, 1993).

Our results of a positive relationship between general firm performance and strategic divergence–convergence suggest two basic behavioral drivers of firm repositioning and strategic group dynamics: a firm’s search behavior, and imitative behavior by low-performing firms. These factors imply a tendency towards strategic divergence for low-performing firms, and convergence for high-performing firms. Integrating managerial performance aspirations into this relationship then establishes a more nuanced perspective including behavioral effects that are specific to performance levels below and specific to performance levels above aspirations. Consistent with insights from the behavioral theory of the firm and behavioral decision theory (Cyert and March, 1963; Greve, 1998a; Kahneman and Tversky, 1979), we find that performance below aspirations leads to increasingly divergent strategic behavior. This divergent strategic behavior mainly seems to result from wider search scopes and increased risk seeking by managers of firms performing below aspirations (Cyert and March, 1963; Greve, 1998a; Kahneman and Tversky, 1979). For firms performing above aspirations, however, our empirical results remain ambiguous. Conflicting predictions from social and economic theories of imitation (Greve, 1998b; Haunschild and Miner, 1997; Lieberman and Asaba, 2006) and arguments on the behavioral implications of high performance (i.e., managerial overconfidence/hubris) (Chen and Miller, 2007; Clapham and Schwenk, 1991; Shefrin, 1999) seem to cancel each other out, leaving us with an opaque effect of performance above aspirations on a firm’s strategic divergence–convergence.

The study further explores important interaction effects. While it is widely accepted that performance aspirations influence strategic behavior, ‘the moderators of the aspiration–strategic behavior relationship have remained understudied’ (Shinkle, 2012: 417). Our findings provide insights into how managers deal with dynamic industry conditions which make past and present firm performance much more difficult to interpret and may even render knowledge on past success factors uninformative. Specifically, our theoretical reasoning and empirical results suggest that dynamic conditions narrow managerial search scopes, and dampen managerial risk seeking, and self-attribution, leading to greater strategic convergence. In contrast, industry munificence seems to enforce these determinants of divergent strategic behavior. These findings highlight the influence of industry characteristics on strategic group dynamics. Even more importantly, however, they show the importance of considering the interplay of firm-level (i.e., performance feedback) and industry-level factors in explaining gradual changes in group membership and group strategies.

Overall, our study thus makes several contributions to strategic group research and the behavioral theory of the firm. It complements extant industry-level research on strategic group dynamics by considering performance feedback as a central firm-level determinant of strategic repositioning within strategic group structures. Through our focus on the role of performance aspirations, we highlight the importance of considering the behavioral decision-making processes when explaining strategic group dynamics. More specifically, by considering the role of performance feedback, the study delineates the conditions under which firms diverge from their strategic groups from those conditions inducing firm–group convergence. These findings on the influence of performance feedback on firm strategic positioning in strategic group structures help explain changes in strategic group strategies, changes in group composition, and advance our understanding of strategic group migration paths. Moreover, our empirical investigation of the moderating influence of industry characteristics on the relationship between performance feedback and strategic repositioning suggests that strategic group dynamics are significantly influenced by firm-, group-, and industry-level factors rather than being the product of just industry-level factors. This draws attention to the fact that greater consideration should be given to the interplay between firm, group, and industry characteristics in the analysis of strategic group dynamics.

The study also makes some methodological contributions to research on strategic group dynamics by introducing a continuous dependent variable that captures changes in the relative positioning of firms and strategic groups rather than operating with a dichotomous outcome variable (‘strategic group membership change’). This allows for a more nuanced analysis of strategic group dynamics. Rather than defining arbitrary cutoff points to assign group membership, our research acknowledges that strategic group members adhere to their group’s strategy to different degrees and that strategic group membership is a matter of degree rather than a binary fact (McNamara et al., 2003). Consistent with this view, we find that firms generally do not ‘leap’ from one strategic group to another – as evidenced by the strategic distance which they cover per year – but that repositioning within an industry’s strategic group structure is a gradual process. Further, our study advances prior research on strategic groups by introducing a novel approach to strategic group identification which blends extant cognitive (e.g., Reger and Huff, 1993) and statistical approaches (e.g., Fiegenbaum and Thomas, 1990) to strategic group identification and combines the strengths of both.

The study further contributes to the behavioral theory of the firm by providing insights on the fundamental question of how aspirations influence firm strategic behavior (Shinkle, 2012). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study which thoroughly examines the influence of performance feedback from benchmarking with strategic groups on firm strategic behavior. Furthermore, by integrating insights from behavioral theory into the cognitive perspective on strategic groups, the study fruitfully combines two areas of research that overlap in their theoretical arguments, but have so far remained disconnected. Finally, by examining the moderating effects of industry dynamism and munificence the study responds to recent calls for a greater consideration of moderators of the aspiration–strategic behavior relationship (Shinkle, 2012).

sec.title: Future research and limitations
sec.p: Following the vast majority of studies on firm aspirations, we examine the influence of financial performance aspirations. However, managerial aspirations are certainly not limited to financial performance. In fact, the behavioral theory of the firm suggests that managers have many aspiration levels. Also social theories of imitation and legitimacy theory suggest that non-financial aspirations may play an important role. An emerging stream of research has thus started to examine the effect of alternative forms of aspirations (e.g., growth and size aspirations; Baum and Locke, 2004; Greve, 2008; Wiklund and Shepherd, 2003). Future research which contrasts the effects of financial and non-financial aspirations on strategic group dynamics would thus further advance our knowledge on the determinants of strategic group dynamics.

Closely linked to the issue of firm aspirations, an alternative fruitful avenue for future research is to analyze the directions firms take when they diverge from their group. Our study differentiates between movements away or towards a firm’s current strategic group and thereby does not yet take advantage of the full dimensionality of the strategic space. Further insights into how factors, such as strategic distance, spur or hamper firms in moving closer to adjacent strategic groups would be of interest for progressing our understanding of strategic group dynamics.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Markus Schimmer is a postdoc at the Institute of Management of the University of St. Gallen. During his PhD studies in St. Gallen, Markus has been a visiting research scholar at the University of Virginia’s Darden School of Business. His research interests are directed towards firm and industry dynamics, with competitive dynamics and industrial organization being his preferred theoretical perspectives. Among his recent publications are an article on the pacing and bundling of competitive moves, and a paper on how market shocks impact patterns of individual firms’ competitive behavior. Further, Markus enjoys contributing to practitioner-oriented outlets on topics as diverse as corporate strategy and contemporary politics. Prior to his PhD studies, Markus worked at the Central Program Office of a multinational firm as the implementation controller of a global growth and efficiency program.
